PARKING ON PUBLIC LOTS
§ 72.001 RESTRICTIONS.
   A person shall not park a vehicle on any parking lot open to the public for
the purpose of doing any of the following:
   (A)   Displaying the vehicle for sale;
   (B)   Washing, polishing, greasing and repairing the vehicle, except for
repairs necessitated by an emergency;
   (C)   Displaying advertising;
   (D)   Selling merchandise from the vehicle except in a duly established
market place or when so authorized or licensed under the ordinances of this
governmental unit; and/or
   (E)   Storage for more than 48 continuous hours.
(Ord. 449, passed 10-20-1994; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020) Penalty,
see §
72.999
§ 72.002 REMOVAL AND IMPOUNDMENT.
   The Police Chief and/or any person or persons designated by the Police Chief
may remove and impound any vehicle from any area where it is parked in
violation of this subchapter.
(Ord. 449, passed 10-20-1994; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
§ 72.003 REGISTERED OWNER.
   The registered owner of any vehicle parked in violation of this subchapter
shall be presumed to be the party who committed the violation.
(Ord. 449, passed 10-20-1994; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
PROHIBITED PARKING
§ 72.005 PROHIBITED PARKING.
   (A)   A vehicle must not be parked, except if necessary to avoid conflict
with other traffic or in compliance with the law or the directions of a police
officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places:
      (1)   On a sidewalk.
      (2)   In front of a public or private driveway.
      (3)   Within an intersection.
      (4)   Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant.
      (5)   On a crosswalk.
      (6)   Within 20 feet of a crosswalk, or if there is not a crosswalk, then
within 15 feet of the intersection of property lines at an intersection of
highways.
      (7)   Within 30 feet of the approach to a flashing beacon, stop sign, or
traffic-control signal located at the side of a highway.
      (8)   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of a
point on the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone, unless a
different length is indicated by an official sign or marking.
      (9)   Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing.
      (10)   Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to a fire station and on
the side of a street opposite the entrance to a fire station within 75 feet of
the entrance if properly marked by an official sign.
      (11)   Alongside or opposite a street excavation or obstruction, if the
stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic.
      (12)   On the roadway side of a vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or
curb of a street.
      (13)   Upon a bridge or other elevated highway structure or within a
highway tunnel.
      (14)   At a place where an official sign prohibits stopping or parking.
      (15)   In a place or in a manner that blocks immediate egress from an
emergency exit conspicuously marked as an emergency exit of a building.
      (16)   In a place or in a manner that blocks or hampers the immediate use
of an immediate egress from a fire escape conspicuously marked as a fire escape
providing an emergency means of egress from a building.
      (17)   On a street or other area open to the parking of vehicles that
results in the vehicle interfering with the use of a curb-cut or ramp by
persons with disabilities.
      (18)   In violation of an official sign restricting the period of time
for or manner of parking.
      (19)   In a place or in a manner that blocks the use of an alley or
parked in the alley.
      (20)   In a place or in a manner that blocks access to a space clearly
designated as a fire lane.
(Ord. passed 8-22-2023)
PARKING ROADWAY
§ 72.010 STANDING OR PARKING CLOSE TO CURB; VIOLATIONS AS CIVIL INFRACTIONS.
   (A)   Excepting angled parking or as otherwise provided in this chapter,
whoever stands or parks a vehicle in a roadway must ensure that:
      (1)   The vehicle is parallel with the edge of the roadway;
      (2)   The vehicle is headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement;
and
      (3)   The wheels of the vehicle that are closest to the curb are within
12 inches of the curb or edge of the roadway.
   (B)   Whoever parks or stands a vehicle in a manner contrary to divisions
(A)(1), (A)(2), and (A)(3) is responsible for a civil infraction.
(Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
IMPOUNDMENT
§ 72.015 IMPOUNDMENT SITUATIONS.
   The Police Chief and/or a person or persons designated by him or her may
remove and impound a vehicle from public or private property in any of the
following situations:
   (A)   The vehicle is in a condition that the continued operation of the
vehicle would constitute an immediate hazard to the public;
   (B)   The vehicle is parked or standing in a manner as to create an
immediate public hazard or an obstruction of pedestrian or vehicular traffic;
   (C)   The vehicle is parked in a posted tow away zone;
   (D)   There is reasonable cause to believe that the vehicle or any part of
the vehicle is stolen;
   (E)   It is necessary to seize the vehicle to preserve evidence of a crime
or there is reasonable cause to believe that the vehicle was used in the
commission of a crime;
   (F)   Removal of the vehicle is necessary in the interest of public safety
because of fire, flood, storm, snow, natural or man-made disaster and other
emergency;
   (G)   The vehicle is hampering the use of private property by the owner or
person in charge of that property or is parked in a manner which impedes the
movement of another vehicle;
   (H)   The driver of the vehicle is taken into custody by the Police
Department and the vehicle would thereby be left unattended;
   (I)   Removal is necessary to permit snow removal, street construction,
cleaning and repair; tree work and other public utility work after at least 24-
hours notice thereof has been posted;
   (J)   A vehicle is unattended and the registered owner of the vehicle has
six or more unpaid outstanding citations for parking violations. In lieu of or
prior to impoundment under this provision, the Police Chief and/or a person or
persons authorized by him or her may attach to the vehicle a device that will
prevent the vehicle from being moved. A fee set by Council resolution shall be
charged for attachment and removal of the device. The device may be removed by
the Police Chief and/or a person or persons designated by him or her if the
violations and fee for attachment and removal are paid, if security is posted
for court appearance on the violations, if the violations are dismissed, or if
it is necessary to impound the vehicle it is unlawful for any person to remove
a device without authorization of the Police Chief and/or a person or persons
designated by him or her;
   (K)   Inoperative vehicles.
      (1)   No person shall park, store, leave or allow to be left upon private
property controlled by him or her, any motor vehicle in a rusted, wrecked, junk
and partially dismantled or inoperative condition whether attended or not,
unless in connection with an auto maintenance or repair business or unless the
vehicle is completely enclosed within a garage.
      (2)   Provided, however, that while no vehicle can be maintained in the
rear yard for a period not to exceed 30 days after notice to remove the vehicle
is served by the city so long as the vehicle is not within 20 feet of an
abutting residential lot.
   (L)   Unregistered vehicles. No person shall park, store, leave or allow to
be left upon the streets, highways or parking lots of the city, any motor
vehicle not displaying current license plates registered to that vehicle; and
   (M)   In any other situation in which impoundment is authorized under the
State Motor Vehicle Code and adopted by the Uniform Traffic Code.
(Ord. 440, passed 1-30-1992; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
§ 72.016 POLICE CHIEF ACTION.
   (A)   If a vehicle is impounded under §
72.015(L), the Police Chief and/or his or her assigns shall proceed in
accordance with the requirements of § 252d of the State Motor Vehicle Code.
   (B)   If a vehicle is impounded under §
72.015(J), the Police Chief and/or his or her assigns shall not require a bond
or cash deposit by the owner of the motor vehicle in excess of $500 in order to
recover the possession of a motor vehicle pending final adjudication of the
case.
(Ord. 440, passed 1-30-1992; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
PARKING OF BOAT, BOAT TRAILER, UTILITY TRAILERS, AND
CAMPERS ON RESIDENTIAL STREETS
§ 72.030 RESTRICTION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to park a boat, boat trailer, utility
trailer, or camper for longer than one hour on any residential street or city
owned property in the city.
(Ord. 427, passed 6-30-1988; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020) Penalty, see
§
72.999
§ 72.031 VIOLATION.
   Any person who violates this subchapter shall be responsible for committing
a civil infraction.
(Ord. 427, passed 6-30-1988; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020) Penalty, see
§
72.999
§ 72.032 ENFORCEMENT.
   All of the provisions of this subchapter shall be enforced by any officer of
the City Police Department, Code Enforcement, or Designee of the Chief of
Police.
(Ord. 427, passed 6-30-1988; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
PARKING METERS
§ 72.045 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CITY. The City of Hamtramck, Wayne County, Michigan.
   CLERK. The City Clerk of the City of Hamtramck, Michigan.
   DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS. The Department of Public Works in the city.
   OPERATOR. Every individual who shall operate a vehicle as the owner thereof
or as the agent, employee and permittee of the owner, or is in actual physical
control of a vehicle.
   PARK or PARKING. The standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon a
street otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of, and while actually
engaged in, receiving or discharging passengers or loading or unloading
merchandise or in obedience to traffic regulations, signs and signals or an
involuntary stopping of the vehicle by reason of causes beyond the control of
the operator of the vehicle.
   PARKING METER. Any mechanical device or meter placed or erected for the
regulation of parking by authority of this subchapter. Each PARKING METER
installed shall indicate by proper legend the legal parking time established by
the city and when operated shall at all times indicate the balance of legal
parking time, and at the expiration of the period shall indicate illegal or
overtime parking.
   PARKING METER SPACE. Any space within a parking meter zone; adjacent to a
parking meter, which is duly designated for the parking of a single vehicle by
lines painted or otherwise durably marked on the curb or on the surface of the
street adjacent to or adjoining the parking meters.
   PARKING METER ZONE. Any street or part thereof upon which parking meters are
to be installed and placed in operation.
   PERSON. Any individual, firm, copartnership, association or corporation.
   POLICE DEPARTMENT. The Police Department in the city.
   STREET. Any public street, avenue, road, alley, highway, lane, path and
other public place or parking lot located in the city and established for the
use of vehicles.
   TREASURER. The City Treasurer in the city.
   VEHICLE. Any device in upon or by which any person or property is or may be
transported upon a street, except a device which is operated upon rails or
tracks.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
§ 72.046 NEED FOR PARKING METERS; RECOMMENDATION.
   (A)   Where it is deemed that because of traffic congestion or other cause,
the public safety is imperiled, the public convenience can be better served and
traffic regulations can be more adequately enforced with the assistance secured
through the installation and maintenance of parking meters, parking meters may
be installed under and in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter.
   (B)   When the Chief of Police deems that conditions on or along any
particular street or streets in the city appear to require the regulation of
traffic by parking meters, he or she shall make or cause to be made through the
Police Department a survey of the situation to determine the need for the
regulation, and if he or she finds a need therefor, he or she shall make a
determination of the fact, and shall file the determination together with his
or her recommendations with the City Council.
   (C)   The recommendations above referred to shall include among other
things:
      (1)   The parking meter zone or zones;
      (2)   Number of parking meter spaces;
      (3)   State the legal parking time in each zone;
      (4)   State the amount of the parking fee for each zone;
      (5)   State the hours during which the use of parking meters shall be in
operation in each zone; and
      (6)   Make any other recommendation that will facilitate the movement or
control of vehicular traffic and eliminate congestion thereof.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
§ 72.047 COUNCIL APPROVAL; EFFECT.
   The Council may by appropriate resolution approve, modify prior to approval
and may disapprove any recommendation. If and when the recommendation is
approved by the Council, the recommendations as approved shall be the
equivalent of adoption by the Council and shall have the same force and effect
as though they had been set forth in a resolution in detail, and shall be
deemed to be regulations promulgated by the Council in the control of traffic
on the streets; provided, however, that nothing herein stated shall be deemed
to prevent the Director of the department whose duty it is to enforce this
subchapter to formulate rules and regulations as authorized by the Charter for
the organization and conduct of the department; provided, further, that the
promulgated regulations by the City Council shall not be effective until signs
have been erected sufficient in size and number to apprise the ordinarily
observant person of the existence of the parking meter regulations. Upon the
approval and the regulations becoming effective, the Chief of Police or their
designee, as hereinafter established, shall thereby be authorized and empowered
to install parking meters and enforce the regulations pertaining thereto as
herein authorized.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
§ 72.048 PARKING METER ZONES.
   All zones shall be set by City Council resolution.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
§ 72.049 PARKING METERS ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   All parking shall be under the direction, supervision and control of
the Chief of Police.
   (B)   The Chief of Police shall have the following powers, duties and
responsibilities:
      (1)   To see that the provisions of this subchapter and the regulations
promulgated in connection therewith are enforced at all times;
      (2)   To install or cause to have installed parking meters in places and
locations as have been determined by Council approval as herein provided;
      (3)   To see or cause to see that the meters are properly maintained,
serviced and kept in a state of good repair so that they will be ready, and
available for use and operation when required;
      (4)   To cause the parking meter spaces to be individually marked or
painted on the street surface, curb or parking lots and the markings to be
continuously maintained, after the location thereof has been designated as
herein provided;
      (5)   To cause regular collections of the sealed coin boxes or containers
from the meters and to deliver the boxes with seals unbroken to the Treasurer
or to the person or persons designated by the Treasurer for the receipt of the
boxes and the handling thereof and the accounting for the contents thereof in
his or her office;
      (6)   To cause to obtain as often as necessary from the Treasurer the
quantities of sealed coin boxes or containers for inserting in the parking
meters to replace those removed containing coins, and to insert the empty boxes
in the meters for use;
      (7)   To cause to keep a daily record of the sealed coin boxes properly
identified, which have been removed from meters and delivered to the Treasurer;
      (8)   To erect or cause to be erected signs in sufficient number and of
suitable size to apprise the ordinarily observant person of the existence of
the parking meter regulation applicable to the parking meter space and zone;
      (9)   To sign or cause their designee to sign any and all complaints that
may be necessary for the proper enforcement of this subchapter;
      (10)   If the vehicle is not towed away, to cause to have issued a notice
of violation to every person, either as owner or operator involving every
vehicle that is illegally parked under the provisions of this subchapter and
the regulations promulgated thereunder; and
      (11)   To make recommendations from time to time to the Council covering
any matters requiring the Council's help in enabling parking to function more
effectively and efficiently.
   (C)   Any and all of the duties hereinabove specified may be performed by
the Chief of Police or by the person or persons by him or her duly authorized.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
§ 72.050 DESIGNATION OF PARKING SPACES.
   (A)   In determining the number of parking spaces that shall be installed in
each parking zone, a minimum of 20 feet in length, or the current industry
standard, shall be allowed for each space for parallel parking when the space
is interior, and a minimum of 18 feet, or the current industry standard, when
the space is at the end of the zone. All parking shall be parallel to curb,
unless the Chief of Police shall determine and the Council shall approve angle
parking in any zone. A minimum of seven feet in width shall be allowed for
parallel parking, and a minimum of eight feet in width shall be allowed for
angle parking.
   (B)   The individual parking spaces shall be designated by lines painted or
durably marked on the surface of the street or on the curbing.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in a way that the vehicle
shall not be entirely within the limits of the space so designated.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020) Penalty, see
§
72.999
§ 72.051 INSTALLATION OF PARKING METERS.
   (A)   After the parking meter zones have been established and the number of
parking spaces determined as herein provided, parking meters shall be installed
upon the curb or sidewalk. Each meter shall be so set as to display a signal
showing legal parking upon the deposit of the appropriate coin or coins which
are lawful money of the United States of America, for the period of time
prescribed by appropriate Council regulation. Each meter shall be so arranged
than upon the expiration of the lawful time limit it will indicate by a proper
visible signal that the lawful parking period has expired, and in cases the
right of the vehicle to occupy the space shall cease and the operator or owner
thereof shall be subject to the penalties hereinafter provided.
   (B)   Each parking meter shall also indicate by a proper legend the coin to
be deposited; the hours during which the use of the meter is required; the
legal parking time established; and when operated, each meter shall indicate
visibly on and by a dial and pointer, or otherwise, the elapsing legal parking
time, and upon the expiration of the time, shall indicate the illegal or over-
parking.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
§ 72.052 OPERATION OF PARKING METERS.
   Except in a period of emergency determined by an officer of the Fire or
Police Department, or in compliance with the directions of a police officer,
when any vehicle shall be parked in any parking space alongside or next to
which a parking meter is located, the operator of the vehicle shall, upon
entering the parking meter space, immediately, cause to be deposited the proper
fees as is required for the parking meter and as is designated by proper
directions on the meter, and, failure to deposit the proper fees shall
constitute a violation of this subchapter. Upon the deposit of fees the parking
space may be lawfully occupied by the vehicle during the period of time which
has been prescribed for the zone in which the parking space is located. If the
vehicle shall remain parked in any parking space beyond the parking time limit
set for the parking space, and if the meter shall indicate that the time has
elapsed and that parking is illegal, then, and in that event, the vehicle shall
be considered as parking overtime and beyond the period of legal parking time,
and the parking shall be deemed a violation of this subchapter.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020) Penalty, see
§
72.999
§ 72.053 PARKING TIME LIMITS.
   Parking a vehicle in a designated space in a parking meter zone shall be
lawful for the period of time specified for that zone as shown by a sign on the
meter or by one or more signs posted along the street in sufficient number and
of sufficient size to apprise the ordinarily observant person of the existence
of the limited period within which lawful sparking can be had along and upon
the street. The parking meters shall be operated in the parking meter zones as
designated by Council resolution. Parking of a vehicle in any parking meter
space for a period longer than that allowed by the sign shall be deemed to be
illegal and a violation of this subchapter.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020) Penalty, see
§
72.999
§ 72.054 METER VIOLATIONS.
   It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this subchapter
for any person:
   (A)   To cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name
of, or operated by the person to be parked overtime, or beyond the period of
legal parking time established for any parking meter zone as herein described;
   (B)   To deposit in any parking meter any coin for the purpose of parking
beyond the maximum legal parking time for the particular parking meter zone and
space;
   (C)   To permit any vehicle to remain in any parking space adjacent to any
parking meter while the meter is displaying a signal indicating that the
vehicle occupying the parking space has already been parked beyond the period
prescribed for the parking space;
   (D)   To park any vehicle across any line or marking of a parking space
meter or in a position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area
designated by the lines or markings;
   (E)   To deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break, destroy and
impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under the provisions of
this subchapter, except persons legally authorized to open the meter; or
   (F)   To deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slugs,
device or metal substance; or other substitute for lawful coins.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020; Am. Ord.
passed 8-22-2023) Penalty, see §
72.999
§ 72.055 TOWAGE AND STORAGE.
   (A)   Whenever any vehicle shall be found parked in any parking meter space
overtime and beyond the period of legal parking time established for the space,
or shall be found parked therein during any period when parking is prohibited
or shall be found parked in violation of any of the provisions of this
subchapter, the vehicle may be removed by, or under the direction of any person
authorized to enforce this subchapter by means of towing the same to the
automobile and vehicle pound, and the removal shall be at the liability of the
owner. Before the owner or person in charge of the vehicle shall be permitted
to remove the same from the pound, he or she shall furnish evidence of his or
her identity and ownership or right to possession, shall sign a receipt for the
vehicle, the enforcing officer may in lieu, or addition, of towing the vehicle
to the pound serve upon the owner or operator of the vehicle, mail, or attach
to the vehicle, a parking violation citation.
   (B)   The violation citation shall state the date and location of where the
violation occurred, the time of violation, the kind of vehicle, the state
license number of each vehicle, and any other facts relevant to the violation.
A copy of the violation citation may be attached to the vehicle in a
conspicuous place, which will notify the owner or operator that the vehicle was
parked in violation of the provisions of this subchapter.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Ord. 264, passed 6-6-1961; Am. Ord. 357, passed
7-2-1974; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020; Am. Ord. passed 8-22-2023)
§ 72.056 REGISTRATION PLATE PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE THAT OWNER IS VIOLATOR.
   In any prosecution or proceeding hereunder, the registration plate displayed
on a motor vehicle shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that
the registered owner of a vehicle as the person who parked the vehicle at the
place where the violation occurred.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
§ 72.057 USE OF FUNDS.
   The fees deposited for parking meters are required and shall be used to
defray the expense of proper regulation of traffic upon the public streets of
the city; to provide for the cost of supervision, regulation, and control of
the parking of vehicles in parking meter zones, and to cover the cost of
purchase, supervision, protection, inspection, installation, operation,
maintenance, control and use of parking meters.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
§ 72.058 DUTIES OF CITY TREASURER.
   (A)   The monies collected in meter fees shall be delivered to and received
by the City Treasurer and the City Controller or his or her authorized
representative, and accounted for and deposited by the City Treasurer as,
directed in this subchapter.
   (B)   The City Treasurer shall keep a detailed record of all monies received
from day to day from the several respective meters throughout the city, and
shall prepare a monthly summary of the receipts from each of the meters. A copy
of the summary shall be available to the City Controller and to any other city
official on request. He or she shall also prepare a monthly report of
miscellaneous monies received from fines and penalties from overtime parking
and submit the same the City Council.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
RESIDENTIAL PARKING AREAS
§ 72.070 DESIGNATION BY CITY COUNCIL.
   The City Council is authorized to designate by resolution an area or areas
within the city in which parking is allowed by special permit. Unless Council
later changes allowed permitted areas by resolution, all metered areas shall be
designated as such.
(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020; Am. Ord. 8-
22-2023)
§ 72.071 RESIDENTIAL DISABILITY PARKING.
   (A)   The Chief of Police, at their discretion, is authorized to designate
or remove, special residential disability parking areas upon residential
streets.
   (B)   A resident with a disability may request that the city designate an
on-street disability parking space in the vicinity of their residence. When
granted, the city will add signage and designation. An initial installation fee
and yearly processing and maintenance fee shall be charged and be set by
Council annually.
   (C)   Special residential disability parking is exclusively for the resident
granted the designated area. Requests shall only be granted for residents with
current State of Michigan handicapped parking credentials and exclusive to
their registered vehicles only. Special signage shall be designated by the
Chief of Police for these areas other than traditional handicapped parking
signage.
   (D)   Special residential disability parking users are subject to all
additional parking regulations and enforcement, including street sweeping and
snow removal restrictions. Use of a designated residential disability parking
space by other than the registered user is not permitted, and vehicles found to
be in violation are subject to removal at the sole discretion of the city by
any means necessary including but not limited to towing.
(Ord. passed 8-22-2023)
§ 72.072 USE OF PERMIT BY UNAUTHORIZED PERSONS.
   It is shall be unlawful to permit an unauthorized person to use a parking
permit to falsify information to obtain these permits or to fail to surrender
the permit to the Chief of Police, or any of his or her designees, on his or
her demand if the permits are used in violation of this subchapter.
(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020; Am. Ord.
passed 8-22-2023) Penalty, see §
72.999
§ 72.073 FALSIFIED INFORMATION TO OBTAIN PERMIT.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to falsify information to obtain a
parking permit, or to fail to surrender the permit to the Chief of Police, or
his or her duly designated agent, on demand if it is used in violation of this
subchapter or to otherwise violate the regulations governing the issuance of
the permits.
(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020) Penalty,
see §
72.999
§ 72.074 PERMIT ISSUED.
   The Chief of Police or their designee, upon application, shall issue a
parking permit to each applicant for each vehicle leased or owned by the
applicant upon presentation of a current vehicle registration with the
appropriate address and fees paid.
(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)
§ 72.075 RESERVED.
§ 72.076 RESERVED.
§ 72.077 FEES.
   There shall be a fee each year of the parking permit as set by Council
resolution.
(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020)

§ 72.079 THREATENING A PERSON LAWFULLY PARKED PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful to threaten, prevent or hinder any person who has
lawfully parked, or is attempting to lawfully park, a vehicle within the city.
(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020) Penalty,
see §
72.999
PARKING ON PRIVATE PREMISES
§ 72.090 UNLAWFUL TO PARK WITHOUT PERMISSION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave or cause to be parked
or left any automobile or other motor vehicle on the premises of another after
having been warned not to do so by word of mouth or sign or otherwise, however,
the person shall not be held in violation of this subchapter unless a complaint
by the property owner is first made; provided that this section, shall not
apply to employees of the city in the discharge of their official duties.
(Ord. 236, passed 9-7-1954; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020) Penalty, see
§
72.999
§ 72.091 PARKING WITHOUT PERMISSION ON PRIVATE PREMISES PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE.
   The presence of an unattended automobile or other motor vehicle on the
premises of one who is not the owner or in control of the automobile or other
motor vehicle shall raise a prima facie presumption that the registered owner
of the automobile or other motor vehicle parked or left or caused to be parked
or left the automobile or other motor vehicle on the premises, and the burden
of proof shall be upon the registered owner to show otherwise.
(Ord. 236, passed 9-7-1954; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020) Penalty, see
§
72.999
§ 72.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Parking on public lots.  Any person who violates any provision of §§
72.001 through
72.003 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished by a fine not to exceed
$500, or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days or by both a fine and imprisonment
in the discretion of the court.
(Ord. 449, passed 10-20-1994)
   (B)   Prohibited parking. Any person who shall violate or fail to comply
with any of the provisions of § 72.005 shall be punishable by a municipal civil
infraction.
   (C)   Impoundment. Any person violating any of the provisions of §§
72.015 and
72.016 shall upon conviction thereof be subject to a find of not more than $500
or to imprisonment for a period of not more than 90 days or to both a fine and
imprisonment in the discretion of the court.
(Ord. 440, passed 1-30-1992)
   (D)   Parking of boat or trailer on residential streets. Any provision of §§
72.030 through
72.032 which describes an act or omission which constitutes a civil infraction
under the terms of the Michigan Vehicle Code, being Public Act 300 of 1949,
being M.C.L.A. §§ 257.1 through 257.923, as amended, shall be processed as a
civil infraction and any person found to have committed a civil infraction may
be ordered to pay a civil fine of not more than $500 and costs.
(Ord. 427, passed 6-30-1988)
   (E)   Parking meters. Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with
any of the provisions of §§
72.045 through
72.051, or
72.054 through
72.058, or the regulations promulgated by the Council in connection therewith,
who shall counsel, aid or abet any violation or failure to comply, shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a
fine of not to exceed $500, or imprisonment for not to exceed 90 days, by both
a fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court.
(Ord. 230, passed 2-3-1953)
   (F)   Operation and time limits. Any person who shall violate or fail to
comply with any of the provisions of §§
72.052 and
72.053 shall be punishable by a municipal civil infraction with a fine set by
City Council annually.
   (G)   Permitted parking areas. Any person convicted of violating any of the
provisions of §§
72.070 through
72.079 shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500 or imprisonment not to
exceed 90 days, or by both a fine and imprisonment.
(Ord. 383, passed 11-28-1978)
   (H)   Parking on private premises. Any person, firm or corporation violating
any provision of §§
72.090 and
72.091 shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500 or
imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or both a fine and imprisonment in the
discretion of the court.
(Ord. 236, passed 9-7-1954; Am. Res. 2020-32.2, passed 5-26-2020; Am. Ord.
passed 8-22-2023)
CHAPTER 73: LOADING REGULATIONS
Section
   
73.001   Establishment
   
73.002   Application for loading zone
   
73.003   Erection of no parking signs
   
73.004   Installation and maintenance fees
   
73.005   Establishment of installation and maintenance fees
   
73.006   Exemptions
 
   
73.999   Penalty
§ 73.001 ESTABLISHMENT.
   Special loading, shipping or receiving zones in front of entrances may be
provided and established under the conditions herein provided.
(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975)
§ 73.002 APPLICATION FOR LOADING ZONE.
   Any owner or occupant of a building adjacent to a street or alley desiring a
certain loading zone immediately in front of an entrance to the building shall
make application to the Chief of Police setting forth all relevant information
and stating the number of feet desired for that purposes. The Chief of Police
shall have authority to grant or refuse the application when in his or her
judgment the public welfare so requires, or to grant the same with the
restrictions or limitations as he or she may deem necessary. In case the
application is granted, the Chief of Police shall issue to the applicant a
permit, or certificate, setting forth the location of the loading, shipping or
receiving zone the number of feet fixed for the zone and other limitations that
may be pertinent. The permit may, at any time, be withdrawn or modified by the
Chief of Police whenever in his or her judgment the public welfare so requires.
(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975) Penalty, see §
73.999
§ 73.003 ERECTION OF NO PARKING SIGNS.
   (A)   The Chief of Police, in order to enforce the provisions of this
chapter, shall erect no parking signs and other appropriate signs marking the
limits of the loading, shipping or receiving zones and setting forth the hours
during which the provisions shall be in effect.
   (B)   During the hours when the provisions applicable to the loading zone
are in effect, no vehicle shall be parked in any zone, except for the purpose
of taking on or discharging merchandise or freight, or for the expeditious
loading or unloading of passengers, and in no case for longer than 30 minutes.
(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975) Penalty, see §
73.999
§ 73.004 INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE FEES.
   The installation and maintenance fees for loading, shipping or receiving
zones established under the terms of this chapter shall be as hereinafter
provided.
   (A)   Where the establishment of a zone does not necessitate the removal of
vehicle parking meters, an installation fee of $1 per foot frontage shall be
paid to the city by the applicant to defray the cost of establishing a zone. In
addition, an annual maintenance fee of $5 shall be paid to the city by the
permit holder on or before May 1 of each year to defray the cost of maintenance
for the following 12-month period, or fraction thereof. In the event of failure
to pay the maintenance fee by May 1, the permit issued hereunder shall
automatically expire.
   (B)   Where the establishment of a loading, shipping or receiving zone
necessitates the removal of one or more vehicle parking meters, an installation
fee of $75 shall be paid to the city by the applicant to defray the cost of
removing the vehicle parking meters and installing signs in each loading,
shipping or receiving zone established on the street. In addition, the annual
maintenance fee of $5 shall be paid to the city by the permit holder on or
before May 1 of each year for the zones established where the vehicle parking
meters were removed, where it was necessary to remove not more than two meter
stalls, and an additional fee of $25 shall be paid to the city by the permit
holder for each meter stall in excess of two which shall have been removed to
provide the zone on or before May 1 of each year, the fee to defray maintenance
and loss of revenues to the city for the 12-month period, or fraction thereof
following. In the event of failure to pay the above maintenance fee by May 1,
the permit issued hereunder shall automatically expire.
(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975) Penalty, see §
73.999
§ 73.005 ESTABLISHMENT OF INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE FEES.
   The installation and maintenance fees for building entrance zones
established under the terms of this chapter shall be as hereinafter provided:
   (A)   Where the establishment of building entrance zones do not necessitate
the removal of vehicle parking meters, an installation fee of $25 shall be paid
to the city by the applicant to defray the cost thereof. In addition, an annual
maintenance fee of $5 shall be paid to the city by the permit holder on or
before May 1 of each year, the fee to defray maintenance for the 12-month
period, or fraction thereof follow the maintenance fee by May 1, any permit
issued hereunder shall automatically expire.
   (B)   Where the establishment of a building entrance zone necessitates the
removal of one or more vehicle parking meters, an installation fee of $75 shall
be paid to the city by the applicant to defray the cost of removing the vehicle
parking meters and installing signs in each building entrance established on
the street. In addition, an annual maintenance fee of $5 shall be paid to the
city by the permit holder on or before May 1 of each year for each building
entrance zone established in an area where the vehicle parking meters existed,
where it was necessary to remove not more than two meter stalls, and an
additional fee of $25 shall be paid to the city by the permit holder for each
meter stall in excess of two which shall have been removed to provide the
building entrance zone on or before May 1 of each year, the fee to defray
maintenance and loss of revenues to the city for the 12-month period, or
fraction thereof following. Failure to pay the fees shall subject the permit
holder to the penalties established for violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975) Penalty, see §
73.999
§ 73.006 EXEMPTIONS.
   The installation and maintenance fees to be paid under the provisions of
this chapter shall not be required of governmental institutions, public or
parochial schools, churches, hospitals, asylums, public libraries, public
museums or charitable institutions.
(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975)
§ 73.999 PENALTY.
   Any violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine
not to exceed $500, or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or both a fine and
imprisonment.
(Ord. 365, passed 5-20-1975)
CHAPTER 74: BICYCLES
Section
   
74.001   Short title
   
74.002   Definitions
   
74.003   Authority
   
74.004   Reserved
   
74.005   Registration and record keeping
   
74.006   Record keeping; payment of fees; rules and regulations promulgated by
City Clerk
§ 74.001 SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter may be referred to as the Bicycle Chapter.
(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003; Am. Res. 2022-49, passed 4-26-2022)
§ 74.002 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BICYCLE. As defined by the Michigan Vehicle Code, Public Act 300 of 1949,
being M.C.L.A. §§ 257.1 et seq. At the time of the adoption of this chapter,
BICYCLE means a device propelled by human power upon which a person may ride,
having either two or three wheels in a tandem or tricycle arrangement, all of
which are over 14 inches in diameter.
(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003; Am. Res. 2022-49, passed 4-26-2022)
§ 74.003 AUTHORITY.
   This chapter is enacted under the authority granted to the city under the
Michigan Vehicle Code, being Public Act 300 of 1949, being M.C.L.A. § 257.606.
(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003; Am. Res. 2022-49, passed 4-26-2022)
§ 74.004 RESERVED.
§ 74.005 REGISTRATION AND RECORD KEEPING.
   (A)   Every owner desiring to register their bicycle with the City Clerk may
do so. The registration shall state the owner’s name, date of birth, residence
address, make of bicycle, serial number, and any other information as the City
Clerk shall require. A registration fee may also be required, which may be
established by Council resolution annually.
   (B)   Upon registration of the bicycle with the City Clerk, he or she shall
cause to attach proof of registration to the bicycle. The City Clerk shall be
authorized to determine the color, type and form of the proof of registration
to be attached to the bicycle, provided that the proof of registration is
numbered and contains the words “City of Hamtramck, MI.” A new proof of a lost,
mutilated or destroyed proof of registration may be secured from the City Clerk
upon filing of an affidavit with him or her, demonstrating the facts, and upon
payment of the appropriate fee.
   (C)   All proof of registration shall remain the property of the city and
shall not be covered, obscured, bent, altered, or defaced in any manner likely
to impair its legibility. No person shall remove, destroy, mutilate, alter, or
counterfeit any proof of registration, or issue any forged or counterfeit proof
of registration.
(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003; Am. Res. 2022-49, passed 4-26-2022) Penalty, see
§
74.999
§ 74.006 RECORD KEEPING; PAYMENT OF FEES; RULES AND REGULATIONS PROMULGATED BY
CITY CLERK.
   (A)   The City Clerk shall keep a complete and accurate record of all
bicycle registrations.
   (B)   All fees required by this chapter shall be established by resolution
annually by the City Council during adoption of the annual budget.
(Ord. 494, passed 10-21-2003; Am. Res. 2022-49, passed 4-26-2022)
CHAPTER 75: TRAFFIC SCHEDULES
Schedule
      
I.   Truck routes
SCHEDULE I. TRUCK ROUTES.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any truck whether loaded or unloaded,
weighing more than 8,000 pounds as determined by its certificate of
registration, to be operated on any street in the city except those streets
hereinafter designated as “truck routes,” provided, however, the provisions of
this section shall not apply to trucks in excess of the weight limit herein
specified when the operation of the truck is necessary for the purposes of
making one or more deliveries or pickups of materials, manufactured products,
goods, wares and merchandise on streets other than those designated “truck
routes” in the city; provided further, that the operation shall be permitted
only for the shortest possible distance when necessary to effect the delivery
or pickup; provided further that trucks operated by the city in connection with
the rendering of necessary service to the residents of the city may be operated
on any or all streets in the city.
   (B)   The streets designated in this chapter as “truck routes” shall be
posted in a conspicuous place upon or at the entrance to the street or highway
or part thereof affected, with a suitable sign indicating the words “truck
route.”
   (C)   It shall be unlawful to park any truck, weighing in excess of 8,000
pounds as determined by its certificate of registration, on any street in the
city. The Chief of Police, for good cause shown, may grant special parking
permits allowing parking of those vehicles, provided the permit is granted for
a definite and specific period of time.
   (D)   All the provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the City
Police Department.
   (E)   A violation of this chapter shall constitute a civil infraction
subjecting the violator to civil fines and court costs as permitted by law.
   (F)   The streets hereinabove referred to as “truck routes” are hereby
designated as follows.
Alpena Avenue from Caniff Avenue to Edwin Avenue
Buffalo Avenue from Caniff Avenue to Holbrook Avenue
Caniff Avenue from Grand Haven Avenue to Buffalo Avenue
Carpenter Avenue from Conant Avenue to Dequindre Avenue
Commor Avenue from Dequindre Avenue to Grand Trunk RR
Conant Avenue from Hamtramck Drive to Carpenter Avenue
Denton Avenue from Conant Avenue to St. Aubin Avenue
Dequindre Avenue from Carpenter Avenue to Poland Avenue
Hamtramck Drive from Conant Avenue to West City Limit
Holbrook Avenue from St. Aubin Avenue to Buffalo Avenue
Joseph Campau Avenue from Denton Avenue to Hamtramck Drive
Lumpkin Avenue from Denton Avenue to Poland Avenue
Miller Avenue from Conant Avenue to McDougall Avenue
Nagel Avenue from Caniff Avenue to Carpenter Avenue
Poland Avenue from Lumpkin Avenue to Dequindre Avenue
Vincent Avenue from Conant Avenue to Marcus Avenue
 
(Ord. 416, passed 5-7-1985; Am. Ord. 471, passed 5-13-1999)
