MECHANICAL GAMES
§ 118.001 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ARCADE HALL. A commercial establishment where five or more mechanical games
are available on the premises for operation by members of the public.
   DISTRIBUTOR. Any person who places any mechanical games, as herein defined,
in any place or establishment, for operation and for the purpose of receiving
any type of compensation.
   MECHANICAL GAME. A pinball machine, a skee ball machine, shuffleboard or
miniature pool table, or any similar machine, instrument, device or contrivance
which is an object of commerce that is operated for a pecuniary obligation,
including but not limited, to those machines activated by the insertion of
United States currency or any tokens.
   OWNER. Any person who owns, operates or conducts any place or establishment
in which any mechanical game, as herein defined, may be operated.
   PERSON. A natural person, partnership, corporation, association or other
legal entity.
   PINBALL MACHINE. A mechanical, electrical or other device, apparatus, or
machine which, for pecuniary obligation, including, but not limited to,
machines activated by insertion of a United States currency or any token, is
available to play or operate and the play or operation of which, whether by
reason of the skill of the operator or the application of an element of chance,
or both, enables the person playing or operating the machine to score points as
a ball or object propelled or stimulated by an electronic or mechanical impulse
touches pins or targets, or entitles the person playing or operating the
machine to score points as a ball or object propelled or stimulated by an
electronic or mechanical impulse touches pins or targets, or entitles the
person playing or operating the machine to replay it at no additional cost.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977)
§ 118.002 LICENSES REQUIRED; DISPLAY.
   (A)   (1)   It shall be unlawful and punishable as a misdemeanor for any
person, in either capacity as a distributor or owner, to allow the maintenance
and/or distribution for the purpose of operation any mechanical game without
having first procured a license for the device pursuant to the provisions of
the City Code of Ordinances.
      (2)   It shall be the joint and several duty of the owner(s) and/or
distributor(s) to post the license or licenses permanently and conspicuously at
the location of the machine in the premises wherein the device is to be
operated and maintained.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful and punishable as a misdemeanor for an owner to
maintain any mechanical game without first obtaining a license for the
commercial establishment, store, or place where the device is being maintained
or operated.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful and punishable as a misdemeanor for any person to
act as a distributor of mechanical games without first obtaining a license as a
distributor.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.003 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INSPECTIONS REQUIRED.
   (A)   License applications for mechanical games shall be made to the City
Clerk in the form and manner required by him or her and in accordance with the
provisions of the City Code of Ordinances, and the application shall state,
among other things:
      (1)   The number of machines or devices intended to be operated on the
premises;
      (2)   The type of machine or device;
      (3)   The name, address and location of the commercial establishment,
store or place where the devices or machines will be located;
      (4)   The name and address of the owner of the commercial establishment,
store or place wherein the devices or machines are located;
      (5)   The name and address of the person(s) responsible for operating or
managing the devices or machines;
      (6)   The name and address of the distributor(s); and
      (7) The location and description of motor vehicle parking facilities
provided for patrons utilizing these devices or machines.
   (B)   If, after the issuance of the license, the licensee desires to operate
other mechanical games, in addition to the number stated in the application for
a license, he or she shall make a new application to the City Clerk in the same
form and manner as the original application for a license.
   (C)   Under this subchapter, the application for a distributor’s license
shall be accompanied by the fingerprints of the applicant, and, in the event
the applicant is a corporation, the application shall be accompanied by the
fingerprints of the officers thereof and the names of the stockholders thereof.
   (D)   Each and every application under this subchapter shall be in writing
and made out in duplicate, one copy being referred to the Chief of Police and
the other copy to the Director of the Department of Public Works.
      (1)   The Chief of Police shall investigate the location wherein it is
proposed to operate the machine to determine whether it violates any
prohibition of the city ordinances, shall ascertain if the owner and/or
distributor is a person of good moral character by an investigation to
determine if he or she was guilty of any criminal activity or offense involving
moral turpitude, and on the basis of aforesaid investigation shall either
approve or disapprove the application.
      (2)   Director of the Department of Public Works shall:
         (a)   Assign an electrical inspector to inspect all wiring and
connections to the devices or machines listed in the application and determine
if the same complies with the city electrical code; and
         (b)   Shall assign a zoning inspector to inspect the location to see
if same complies with the pertinent sections of the city zoning regulations.
Further, the Director of the Department of Public Works shall determine whether
applicant’s designated building has a proper certificate of occupancy.
      (3)   No license shall be issued to any applicant unless approved by the
Chief of Police and the Director of the Department of Public Works.
   (E)   Within 90 days after receipt of the application and the related
application fees, the Chief of Police and Director of the Department of Public
Works shall approve or disapprove the application.
   (F)   If the Chief of Police and Director of the Department of Public Works
disapproves an application for a license relating to mechanical games, the
reasons for the disapproval shall be stated in writing. Further, the Chief of
Police and the Director of the Department of Public Works shall have full and
absolute power to disapprove an application for either a new license or renewal
of a previous license for any of the following specified reasons:
      (1)   Applicant makes a false statement of material fact in the
application;
      (2)   Applicant has been found guilty of criminal conduct or offense
involving moral turpitude;
      (3)   Applicant violates this subchapter; or
      (4)   Applicant is delinquent in taxes owed to a municipality.
   (G)   A person whose application for a license is disapproved shall not be
eligible to reapply for a license until the expiration of one year after the
date of the Chief of Police’s or the Superintendent of Building and Safety
Engineering’s disapproval.
   (H)   A license issued pursuant to this section of the subchapter shall be
valid for one year expiring annually on May 1.
   (I)   A license is not assignable or transferable.
   (J)   A license may be renewed annually upon the submission of an
application provided by the City Clerk and upon the licensee’s payment of the
annual license fee.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.004 ISSUANCE OF LICENSES AND RELATED FEES.
   (A)   Upon meeting the above requirements, the City Clerk is authorized to
issue a license upon the payment of the following annual fees.
 
Distributor            $200
Owner                  $50
Each machine or device $25
 
   (B)   The applicant must also pay for any inspections by the Director of the
Department of Public Works which were necessitated in the processing of the
application.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.005 PROHIBITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee to permit any minor to operate
or play any mechanical game, in violation of the following age limitations and
restrictions.
      (1)   Unless accompanied by a parent or guardian, a minor prior to his or
her fifteenth birthday shall not be allowed to enter, loiter, remain,
congregate or play any mechanical game in an arcade hall.
      (2)   Unless accompanied by a parent or guardian, a minor between his or
her fifteenth and seventeenth birthdays shall not be allowed to enter, loiter,
remain, congregate or play any mechanical game in an arcade hall on any day
between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 1:00 a.m.
   (B)   Nothing herein contained shall be construed as permitting the issuance
of a license for any slot machine or as legalizing any coin operated machine or
device in which is incorporated any gambling feature, and all use thereof for
gambling of any kind is prohibited.
   (C)   It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association to
operate any device regulated by this subchapter which would display, expose,
produce or emit any motion picture, printed matter, advertisement, writing,
song, recitation, speech, music or other matter that is obscene, indecent,
pornographic or contrary to good morals.
   (D)   It is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association
holding a license under this subchapter to permit the operation of a device, as
defined in §
118.001 between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. of any day.
   (E)   Nothing in this subchapter shall be construed as prohibiting the
keeping and use of pool tables, billiard tables, bowling alleys, shuffle boards
or other licensed amusements and their usual appurtenances in places duly
licensed and operated under applicable regulations of the city.
   (F)   It shall be unlawful for the arcade owners and/or operators to allow
anyone under the age of 17 years to patronize their establishment(s) in
violation of the city curfew regulations.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977) Penalty, see §
118.999
MERCHANDISE, SERVICE AND MUSIC VENDING MACHINES
§ 118.020 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   COIN OPERATED MUSIC DEVICE. A piano, phonograph, juke box or any similar
machine or contrivance which emits recitations, songs, speeches or music upon
the insertion of a coin.
   MERCHANDISE VENDING MACHINE. Any mechanical device which, upon insertion of
a coin, returns the value in merchandise of the sum thus inserted or renders a
service for same.
   PERSON, FIRM, CORPORATION or ASSOCIATION. Any person, firm, corporation or
association which own any machine; the person, firm, corporation or association
in whose place of business any machine is placed for use by the public; and the
person, firm, corporation or association in whose place of business any machine
is placed for use by the public; and the person, firm, corporation or
association having control over the machine.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977)
§ 118.021 LICENSE REQUIRED; DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   (A)   Any person, firm, corporation or association displaying for public
patronage or keeping for operation any merchandise, service, and/or music
vending machine, as herein defined by §
118.020 shall be required to obtain a license from the city. Application for
the license shall be made to the City Clerk upon a form to be supplied for that
purpose.
   (B)   The license or licenses herein provided for shall be posted
permanently and conspicuously at the location of the machine in the premises
wherein the device is to be operated or maintained to be operated.
   (C)   The license may be transferred from one machine or device to another
similar machine upon application to the City Clerk to the effect and the giving
of a description and the serial number of the new machine or device. Not more
than one machine shall be operated under one license and the applicant or
licensee shall be required to secure a license for each and every machine
displayed or operated by him or her.
   (D)   A license shall not be transferrable from person to person, and shall
be usable only at the place and by the person designated in the license.
However, if the licensee shall move his or her place of business to another
location within the city, the license may be transferred to a new location upon
application to the City Clerk, giving the street and number of the new
location. The new location shall be approved by the Chief of Police and the
Director of the Department of Public Works in the same manner as provided in §
118.022 of this subchapter.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.022 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INSPECTIONS REQUIRED.
   (A)   The application for a merchandise, service or music vending machine
license shall contain the following information:
      (1)   Name and address of the applicant, age, date and place of birth;
      (2)   Prior criminal convictions of applicant, if any;
      (3)   Place where machine or device is to be displayed or operated and
the business conducted at that place; and
      (4)   Description of machine to be covered by the license, mechanical
features, name of manufacturer, serial number.
   (B)   No license shall be issued to any applicant unless he or she shall be
over 18 years of age and a citizen or permanent resident of the United States.
   (C)   Application for a merchandise service or music vending machine license
shall be made out in duplicate, one copy being referred to the Chief of Police
and the other copy to the Director of the Department of Public Works.
      (1)   The Chief of Police shall ascertain if the vending machine
applicant is a person of good moral character, by an investigation to determine
if he or she was guilty of any criminal offense and based on the investigation
either approve or disapprove the application.
      (2)   The Director of the Department of Public Works shall inspect his or
her files to see if the commercial establishment wherein the licensed machine
is located complies with the municipal ordinances of the city, and has a valid
certificate of occupancy, and based upon this investigation either approve or
disapprove the application.
   (D)   A license issued under §§
118.020 through
118.024 of the subchapter shall be valid for one year expiring annually on June
30.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.023 ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; LICENSE FEE.
   (A)   Every applicant, before being issued a license shall pay an annual
license fee, pursuant to the city licensing ordinances, for the privilege of
operating or maintaining for operation each machine, as defined in §§
118.001 and
118.020.
   (B)   No license issued under this subchapter shall be issued to any
applicant unless approved by the Chief of Police and the Director of the
Department of Public Works.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.024 PROHIBITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association
holding a license under this subchapter to operate any machine as defined §
118.020, of this subchapter which has not been approved and/or listed by a
recognized testing laboratory such as Underwriters Laboratory (U.L.) and
Factory Mutual Research Corporation.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a coin operated music
device any day from 2:00 a.m. to 7:00 a.m., except when the Liquor Control
Commission permits extension of its normal hours beyond 2:00 a.m.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful to electrically connect food and beverage vending
machines by the use of extension cords.
   (D)   Nothing in this subchapter shall in any way be construed to authorized
license or permit any gambling devices whatsoever, or any mechanism that has
been judicially determined to be a gambling device, or in any way contrary law,
or that may be contrary to any future laws of the state.
   (E)   All electrical connections made by the flexible cord that supplies the
machine shall be of the three-wire grounding type. Vending machines shall be so
as not to overload any existing circuit that it may be attached to.
   (F)   For the installation of these vending machines that require the
installation of an electrical circuit or the extending of a circuit, an
electrical permit and inspection is required.
   (G)   The installation of electrical circuits shall be made by an electrical
contractor and an electrical permit secured from the city offices.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977) Penalty, see §
118.999
GENERAL PROVISIONS FOR MECHANICAL GAMES, PINBALL MACHINES AND MUSIC VENDING
MACHINES
§ 118.035 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (A)   Every person licensed under §§
118.001 through
118.005 and §§
118.020 through
118.024 is subject to the right, which is hereby expressly reserved, to revoke
or suspend the license should the license, directly or indirectly permit the
operation of any mechanical game, coin operated merchandise, service or music
vending device contrary to the provisions of the city, or the law of the state.
   (B)   The license may be suspended or revoked if the licensee is found
guilty of any criminal offense or offense involving moral turpitude.
   (C)   (1)   The license may be suspended or revoked by the municipal court
judge after written notice to the licensee by the court clerk, which notice
shall specify the ordinance or law violations with which the licensee is
charged and if, after a hearing, the licensee is found to be guilty of the
violation, ten days notice of hearing shall be given the licensee.
      (2)   At the hearing the licensee and his or her attorney may present and
submit evidence of witnesses in his or her defense.
   (D)   It shall be the duty of police officers to make routine inspections of
all devices, and if any unlawful practices are observed in connection
therewith, they shall report the same to the Chief of Police for the action as
he or she may deem proper, and the Chief of Police may recommend the immediate
revocation or suspension of the license.
   (E)   A licensee whose license is revoked as a consequence of a violation of
this subchapter shall be ineligible to apply for a license for a period of one
year after the revocation.
   (F)   A suspended or revoked license shall be returned immediately to the
office of the City Clerk by the licensee.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.036 SEIZURE AND DESTRUCTION OF MACHINES.
   If the Chief of Police shall have reason to believe any mechanical amusement
device is used as a gambling device, the machine may be seized by the police
and impounded, and if upon trial of the exhibitor for allowing it to be used as
a device, the exhibitor be found guilty, then the machine shall be destroyed by
the police.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977)
BILLIARD ROOMS, POOL HALLS AND BOWLING ALLEYS
§ 118.050 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person or persons, firm or corporation shall operate, conduct or maintain
a billiard room, pool room or bowling alley, or any combination of them, within
the city without having first obtained from the City Clerk of the city a
license therefor.
(Ord. 70, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.051 APPLICATION.
   (A)   Any person or persons, firm or corporation desiring to open or
establish a billiard room, pool room or bowling alley, or any combination of
them, within the city shall first make application for a license therefor to
the City Clerk of the city, setting forth in the application his or her age and
correct name, post office address and residence, the length of time he or she
has resided within this state, and where, and his or her place of residence for
the past five years immediately before the time of the application.
   (B)   In case the applicant for a license is a corporation authorized to do
business in this state, the application shall be made by the agent of the
corporation who will have principal charge of the place proposed to be
established, and the application shall contain all of the statements and
furnish all the facts in respect to the agent as are required in the case of a
private individual herein. In case of a partnership, each active partner in the
business shall join in the application for the permit and shall furnish all of
the information required of an individual applicant. The application shall also
set forth the street and number of the place where the business is proposed to
be conducted, together with the description of the property as to lot number
and subdivision. No license shall be granted to any person under the age of 21
years, nor to any person who has been convicted of a felony, nor to any firm or
corporation or copartnership, of which any number has been convicted of a
felony. No license shall be granted to any person, firm, corporation or
copartnership, to operate, conduct, or maintain a billiard room, pool room or
bowling alley, or any combination of them, within a radius of 1,000 feet of any
other billiard room, pool room or bowling alley, provided, however, that the
provision shall not apply to the renewal of licenses for business places
operated and licensed prior to 1933.
(Ord. 70, passed 8-2-1928; Am. Ord. 97, passed 7-21-1931)
§ 118.052 LICENSE FEE.
   The sum of $5 shall accompany the application as a license fee, and the
license shall entitle the holder thereof to conduct the business until May 1
following the issuance of the license, unless sooner revoked by the City
Council.
(Ord. 70, passed 8-2-1928; Am. Ord. 116, passed 7-6-1933) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.053 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   POOL ROOM or BILLIARD ROOM. Any room, place or premises in which persons are
permitted to play billiards or pocket billiards, (commonly known as POOL) and
for which pay, money, or its equivalent, or any check or counter, or ticket, in
lieu of money, is paid or received,
(Ord. 70, passed 8-2-1928)
§ 118.054 PROHIBITIONS REGARDING MINORS.
   (A)   No person or persons, firm or corporation licensed as prescribed in
this subchapter shall permit or suffer any gambling to be carried on in the
licensed premises, nor knowingly employ in carrying on the business any person,
who has been convicted of a felony, nor permit or suffer any child, actually or
apparently under the age of 14 years, to play billiards or pool or to bowl on
the licensed premises, or to be or remain in or upon the premises unless
accompanied by the parents or guardian of the child, and it is hereby made the
duty of all proprietors, owners or managers, licensees or anyone connected with
the licensed premises of operating or maintaining any commercial billiard
parlor to ascertain the correct age of any person subject to the regulation by
this section. A violation by a licensee of this requirement shall be the basis
for a suspension and revocation of his or her license.
   (B)   A person less than 14 years of age may be permitted to play in the
bowling alley between 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.
(Ord. 70, passed 8-2-1928; Am. Ord. 318, passed 7-14-1969) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.055 INTOXICANTS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person or persons, firm or corporation licensed as prescribed in
this subchapter shall permit or suffer the sale or possession within the
billiard room, pool room or bowling alley of any habit-forming drugs or any
appliances for administering the same, nor permit nor suffer the sale or
possession in the aforesaid rooms or places of any intoxicating liquors.
   (B)   The phrase “intoxicating liquor” shall be construed to include
alcohol, brandy, whiskey, rum, gin, beer, ale, porter and wine, and, in
addition thereto, any spirituous, vinous, malt or fermented liquors, liquids
and compounds, whether medicated, proprietary, patented or not, or by whatever
name called, containing one-half of 1%, or more, of alcohol by volume, which
are fit for beverage purposes.
(Ord. 70, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.056 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (A)   Every license issued hereunder shall be revoked for any of the
following causes:
      (1)   Intoxicating liquors are herewith sold or drunk on the premises, or
that persons under the influence of intoxicating liquor are permitted to
frequently be in or remain on the premises;
      (2)   Gambling in any form is permitted in or about the premises;
      (3)   The licensee conducts the place in a manner as to permit the same
to become a public nuisance; and
      (4)   Fights, brawls, or other indecent and immoral practices are
permitted therein to an extent as to break the public peace or disturb the good
order of the community.
   (B)   In any of the foregoing cases the Council of the city shall revoke the
license and give notice of the revocation to the holder.
   (C)   (1)   For the purpose of enforcing these provisions for revocation the
Council may act on its own initiative or on complaint of any resident. When the
revocation is sought the City Clerk shall, at the request of the Council, give
a written notice to the licensee personally, or by leaving the same with his or
her agent or employee at his or her place of business, in which notice shall be
stated the charge made against him or her for which revocation of his or her
license is sought, the time and place at which he or she may appear to defend
against the charges, which time shall be not sooner than three full days from
the serving of the notice.
      (2)   For the hearing, the Council may subpoena witnesses in the same
manner as witnesses are now subpoenaed in criminal cases in District Court. The
hearing need not follow the strict legal requirement of court trials. If, after
the investigation the Council is convinced that the charges have been
sustained, it shall revoke the license. If the Council shall determine that the
license shall be revoked, the City Clerk shall personally notify the licensee,
or his or her agent or employee in charge of his or her place, in writing, and
the license shall be revoked from and after midnight of the day.
(Ord. 70, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.057 PREVIOUS REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   No license shall be issued to any person who has been previously licensed to
conduct a billiard room, pool room or bowling alley, whose license shall have
been revoked during the year immediately preceding the time of making an
application, as herein mentioned, nor to any firm or corporation, any member of
which has been licensed to conduct a billiard room, pool room or bowling alley,
whose license has been revoked during the year immediately preceding the time
of the making of the application therefor.
(Ord. 70, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.058 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   All billiard rooms, pool rooms and bowling alleys within the city shall be
closed not later than 12 midnight, Eastern Standard Time, of each day and kept
closed until 7:00 a.m. of the following day.
(Ord. 70, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.059 WINDOW RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   (1)   Where there is a window, or windows, in the room or place, at
least the lower one-third part of the window or windows shall be of clear
glass, and shall not be screened or curtained at any time of the day or night,
nor shall there be any article or thing in the rear of the window or windows
its to prevent a full, clear and unobstructed view of the room or place.
      (2)   No enclosed box or stall or private room and no partitions forming
boxes or stalls or private rooms shall be permitted.
      (3)   There shall be no interior door or entrance and the door or other
doors entering the rooms or places shall have therein a section of clear glass
sufficient to afford a clear view of the room or places from the outside.
      (4)   All billiard rooms or pool rooms or bowling alleys shall have a
floor space of at least 400 square feet, and shall be kept in a clean and
sanitary manner.
   (B)   None of these provisions, however, shall be construed to prevent the
maintenance of wash rooms or toilet rooms for proper purposes, or the
maintaining of closets for store purposes exclusively.
(Ord. 70, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
PUBLIC SHOWS, EXHIBITIONS AND AMUSEMENTS
§ 118.070 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   No person or persons, company or companies, shall exhibit or maintain in the
city, any circus, menagerie, carnival, play, game or theatrical exhibition, or
give any concert, vocal or instrumental or exhibit any natural or artificial
curiosity, or give a show of any kind for which pay is demanded or received,
without first obtaining a license from the City Clerk of the city, and for any
license granted for any business, purpose or object herein specified there
shall be collected in advance from the person or persons, firm or corporation
receiving the same the following fee.
   (A)   The license fee for a circus or menagerie, or both, where an admission
fee is charged, shall be $150 for the first day upon which an exhibition shall
occur and $100 for each subsequent day.
   (B)   (1)   The license fee for a carnival or open-air exhibition which
consists of or comprises an aggregation of amusements, exhibitions, shows,
games and like amusements, shall be the sum of $25 per day, to be paid in
advance; and, before the granting of a permit for the exhibition or carnival,
the management thereof shall submit to the Director of Public Works of the city
a schedule or list of the amusements, exhibitions, shows, games and like
amusements comprising the carnival or exhibition, and the Director of Public
Works shall examine the same and make investigation thereabout and if satisfied
that the amusement, exhibitions, shows, games and like amusements are proper,
shall endorse the application with his or her approval, but unless the approval
be endorsed upon the application no license for the carnival or open air
exhibition shall be issued by the City Clerk. The payment of the sum of $25, as
aforesaid, shall be held to cover and include the license fee otherwise
chargeable for each amusement, exhibition, show, game and like amusement
operated in connection with the carnival or open air exhibition.
      (2)   Provided, that before any license shall be granted under divisions
(A) or (B) of this section there shall be deposited by the applicant for the
license, with the City Clerk, a cash bond of not more than $500 conditioned
that no damage will be done to the streets, sewers, trees or adjoining
property, and that no dirt, paper, litter or other debris will be permitted to
remain upon the streets or upon any private property by the licensee, and
containing other conditions as the City Clerk may require. The City Clerk shall
fix the amount of the bond up to $500 depending upon the nature and size of the
property equipment of the applicant, the length of haul and other pertinent
facts.
   (C)   The license fee for a zoological garden, permanently located and
established in the city shall be the sum of $25 annually.
   (D)   The license fee for all baseball parks or grounds, where professional
baseball is played, shall be the sum of $25 annually.
   (E)   The license fee for a play or theatrical exhibition, except as
hereinafter specified, shall be the sum of $10 for the first day and $5 for
each subsequent day.
   (F)   The license fee for a concert, vocal or instrumental or operatic
performance, shall be $10 for the first day and $5 for each succeeding day.
   (G)   The license fee for concert, vocal or instrumental or operatic
performances, moving pictures, vaudeville acts, minstrel show or other form of
entertainment given in the open air or in a tent within the limits of the city
shall be $15 a month, the sum payable in advance and the license to be granted
for the term of four months only; provided, that during the performance of any
of the above enumerated entertainments, no articles, souvenirs or prizes shall
be sold, donated or given away for advertising purposes; and provided further,
that during the rendition of any show as above enumerated it shall be unlawful
to advertise, give away or sell any medicine, salve, lineament or other
ingredient for the cure of the ailment of man or beast.
   (H)   The license fee for a museum permanently located and established in
the city shall be the sum of $50 annually in advance.
   (I)   The license fee for a museum temporarily located in the city shall be
the sum of $10 for the first day and $5 for each succeeding day.
   (J)   The license fee for a whirligig, merry-go-round, shooting gallery or
games of like character, permanently located in the city shall be the sum of
$50 annually in advance.
   (K)   The license fee for a whirligig, shooting gallery or games of like
character, temporarily located in the city, shall be the sum of $10 for the
first day and $5 for each succeeding day.
   (L)   The license fee for the exhibition of any natural or artificial
curiosity shall be the sum of $10 for the first day and $5 for each succeeding
day.
   (M)   The license fee for all observation stands shall be the sum of $100
annually, payable in advance.
   (N)   The license fee for roller and ice skating rinks, penny exhibits and
phonographic exhibits, permanently located in the city, shall be the sum of $50
annually, payable in advance.
   (O)   The license fee for roller and ice skating rinks, penny exhibits and
phonographic exhibits, temporarily, located in the city, shall be the sum of
$10 for the first day and $5 for each succeeding day.
   (P)   The license fee for all concert, musical and lecture halls shall be
the sum of $50 annually, payable in advance; provided, that the sum so paid
shall be in lieu of any other sum required to be paid for a license, for any
performance, theatrical, musical or otherwise, that may occur therein.
   (Q)   The license fee for moving picture shows and all shows of a like
character, permanently located with the city, shall be the sum of $25 per show
for shows having a capacity of not more than 500 persons. The license fee for
all shows with a larger seating capacity than 500 persons shall be $25 per
annum plus $5 for each additional 100 seats, or fraction thereof, over 500.
Provided, however, that the maximum license fee for the shows shall be $50 per
annum. All applications for licenses for moving picture shows and all shows of
like character shall specify the number of seats in each show for which a
license is desired and all statements contained in the application shall be
subscribed and sworn by the applicant before a notary public.
   (R)   The license fee for all opera houses and play houses where theatrical,
dramatic and operatic, or so-called vaudeville or burlesque shows are given,
shall be the sum of $100 annually, payable in advance. Provided, that the sum
so paid shall be in lieu of any other sum or sums of money required to be paid
for a license, for any performance, theatrical, musical or otherwise that may
occur therein.
   (S)   The license fee for all amusement parks or amusement places,
maintaining and operating six or more than six kinds or variety of exhibits,
shows or amusements, shall be the sum of $1,000 annually, payable in advance.
   (T)   The license fee for any public entertainment or amusement not already
designated, and for which pay is demanded or received, shall be the sum of $10
for the first day and $5 for each succeeding day.
(Ord. 63, passed 1-22-1929; Am. Ord. 147, passed 8-29-1935) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.071 CITY CLERK AUTHORIZATION.
   The City Clerk of the city is hereby authorized to issue, to the person or
persons entitled to the same under the provisions of this subchapter, a proper
license for the purposes specified, upon the payment of the amount of the
license fee therefor to the City Treasurer of the city and upon the
continuation of any license fee from day to day. It shall be the duty of the
Chief of Police of the city, or his or her subordinates to see that the proper
license fee for the continuance is paid in advance and a receipt therefor,
countersigned by the City Clerk, delivered to the person properly entitled to
the license.
(Ord. 63, passed 1-22-1929)
§ 118.072 EXEMPTIONS.
   This subchapter shall not extend to any exhibition by the pupils of any
private or public school, or to any musical entertainment given by the members
and for the benefit of any resident musical society, or to any exhibition of
painting, engraving, sculpture of fine art displayed by any citizen of the city
in the course of his or her ordinary business, or to any concert or musical
entertainment, fair, festival or lecture for the benefit of any church or
benevolent object where the entire proceeds of the concert, musical
entertainment, fair, festival or lecture shall be given to the church or other
benevolent object, or to any game of baseball, cricket, lacrosse, football,
tennis or other games or amusements managed and given by any resident
association, club or company where the entire proceeds of the game, amusement,
entertainment or exhibition shall be wholly received and given for the benefit
of the resident association, club or company.
(Ord. 63, passed 1-22-1929)
§ 118.073 DISORDERLY CONDUCT PROHIBITED.
   No person or persons, firm or corporation receiving a license under this
subchapter shall permit in, or about, his, her, or their, place of amusement or
exhibition any disorderly conduct, or the use of any language inciting
disorderly conduct, or permit the sale, giving away, delivering, drinking, or
use of any beer, wine, malt, or intoxicating liquor or beverage of any
description, or have connected with the place of amusement or exhibition, by
side entrances or otherwise, any bar, saloon, or place where malt or
intoxicating liquors are sold or given away, or permit the place of amusement
or exhibition to become and be a place for the resort of thieves, prostitutes
or other disorderly persons.
(Ord. 63, passed 1-22-1929) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.074 NUISANCE PROHIBITED.
   No licensee shall permit the exhibition or public entertainment for which he
or she has received the license to become a public nuisance, and shall, in the
carrying on of the same, observe ordinances of the city and laws of the state.
Failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall be sufficient
grounds for the revocation of the license by the City Council.
(Ord. 63, passed 1-22-1929) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.075 BOND.
   The City Clerk is hereby authorized to issue licenses to the parties and for
the purposes aforesaid upon the person, persons, company or companies executing
a bond to the city in the penal sum of $1,000 with two sufficient sureties,
conditioned for the faithful observance of this subchapter and the Charter and
ordinances of the city.
(Ord. 63, passed 1-22-1929) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.076 GROUNDS TO REFUSE ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   The City Clerk may refuse to issue licenses when the purpose for which the
license is requested shall be so notoriously indecent, filthy, vile or
blasphemous as to be subversive of public morals and a reproach to the
community; provided, however, that in case the City Clerk of the city shall
refuse to issue a license as hereinbefore provided, the applicant may appeal
from the decision of the City Clerk to the City Council, which may, upon
hearing of the facts, order the license to be issued.
(Ord. 63, passed 1-22-1929)
§ 118.077 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   TEMPORARILY LOCATED. The continuous location and operation of an amusement
or public entertainment at any one place for a period of less than six months.
(Ord. 63, passed 1-22-1929)
§ 118.078 REVOCATION.
   The City Council may revoke any license granted under this subchapter upon
proof submitted to the City Council of the violation of, or failure to comply
with, the statutes of the state or any ordinance of the city.
(Ord. 63, passed 1-22-1929)
§ 118.079 LICENSE EXPIRATION.
   All licenses issued under the provisions of this subchapter for amusements
or exhibitions permanently located in the city shall expire on September 15
following the issuance of the license unless sooner revoked by the City Council
for cause.
(Ord. 63, passed 1-22-1929) Penalty, see §
118.999
PUBLIC DANCE HALL
§ 118.095 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PUBLIC DANCE HALL. Any room, place or space in which a public dance or
public ball shall be held, or hall or academy in which classes in dancing are
held and instructions in dancing are given for hire, or where admission can be
had by payment of a fee or by the purchase, possession or presentation of a
ticket or token, or in which a charge is made for care of clothing or property,
or where the public generally may gain admission with or without payment of a
fee.
(Ord. 56, passed 8-2-1928)
§ 118.096 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person or persons, firm or corporation shall hold any public dance or
public ball, or hold classes in dancing, or give instructions in dancing for
hire in any hall or academy in the city until the operation and maintenance of
the hall shall have been licensed according to the provisions of this
subchapter.
(Ord. 56, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.097 OWNER’S DUTY.
   No owner, proprietor, lessee, manager or other person shall allow any hall
or academy to be used for the purposes stated in §
118.095 without having obtained the license for the purpose from the City
Clerk.
(Ord. 56, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.098 RIGHT TO INSPECT.
   Whenever an application shall have been filed with the City Clerk of the
city for a license to operate and maintain a public dance hall, it shall be the
duty of the City Clerk and the Chief of Police, respectively, to make
inspection of the place to be used as a public dance hall and, upon full
compliance with the rules and regulations of the respective departments
relative to the safety, health, convenience and comfort of the public, the City
Clerk shall issue a certificate of inspection and recommendation of permission,
which shall be approved by and the Chief of Police which certificate approved
as aforesaid, shall thereupon bring the matter of application before the City
Council for its approval or rejecting and, if the application shall be
favorably passed upon by the City Council, by resolution duly adopted, the City
Clerk shall forthwith issue the license to operate the public dance hall upon
the payment to the City Treasurer by the applicant of the license fee
hereinafter provided for.
(Ord. 56, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.099 PROPER VENTILATION, TOILETS AND DRINKING FOUNTAINS REQUIRED.
   It shall be the duty of the health officer, before approving of the
certificate of inspection provided for in §
118.098, to require the hall or academy to have proper provisions made for
ventilation and to be supplied with sufficient toilet conveniences and with a
sanitary drinking fountain or fountains, the number to be regulated by the
Board of Health.
(Ord. 56, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.100 REFUSAL TO GRANT LICENSE.
   The City Council may refuse to grant a license to any applicant and may
revoke any license already issued to any owner, proprietor, lessee or manager
of any public dance upon proof submitted to the City Council of the violation
by the applicant or owner, proprietor, lessee or manager of any public dance
hall, of any statute of the state for which violation a fine may be imposed or
a sentence of imprisonment in the state prison, the Wayne County Jail may
attach or be imposed, and the Council may revoke any license already issued to
any owner, proprietor, lessee or manager of any public dance hall upon proof
submitted to the City Council of the violation of any regulation of the city
regulating, controlling or in any way relating to health, sanitation, fire
protection or the public peace, or for the violation of any of the provisions
of this subchapter.
(Ord. 56, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.101 CHIEF OF POLICE.
   Any proprietor, lessee, owner or manager operating a public dance hall or
academy under the provisions of this subchapter, and in whose place there shall
be held any public dance of any character, kind or description, shall at all
times open the dance hall for inspection by the Chief of Police or any member
of the Police Department. The Chief of Police is hereby authorized, and it is
hereby made his or her duty, to inspect or cause to inspected, all licensed
dance halls.
(Ord. 56, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.102 DISORDERLY CONDUCT PROHIBITED.
   No owner, proprietor, lessee or manager of any public dance hall receiving a
license under this subchapter shall permit any disorderly conduct or the use of
any immoral, profane or indecent language, or permit the hall or place of
amusement to become a place of resort of thieves, prostitutes or other
disorderly persons.
(Ord. 56, passed 8-2-1928; Am. Ord. 154, passed 12-17-1935) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.103 MARATHON DANCING PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any proprietor, lessee, operator or manager of any
dance hall or academy, or any other place of public assemblage, or any other
person, firm or corporation for gain or profit to permit marathon and/or
endurance dancing, running, walking or any other endurance contest, in any
public dance hall or academy or any other place of public assemblage in the
city.
(Ord. 127, passed 6-28-1934) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.104 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No public dance hall shall be kept open, nor shall any dancing or amusement
of any kind be allowed therein between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m.
Eastern Standard Time.
(Ord. 56, passed 8-2-1928; Am. Ord. 154, passed 12-17-1935) Penalty, see §
118.999
§ 118.105 LICENSE FEE.
   The license fee for all public dance halls shall be the sum of $1 and the
license when issued shall entitle the holder thereof to operate and maintain a
public dance hall until May 20 next following the issuance of the license,
unless sooner revoked by the City Council for cause.
(Ord. 56, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
118.999
GAMING APPARATUS
§ 118.120 SEARCH WARRANTS.
   The Chief of Police or his or her designee, may, upon complaint made under
oath, request a search warrant, when satisfied that there is a reasonable cause
to search for and seize any gaming apparatus or implements used or kept and
provided to be used in unlawful gaming in any gaming house or place resorted to
for unlawful gaming, or any articles, equipment, furniture, loud speakers and
amplifying apparatus, adding machines, calculators, money changers and boxes
and money found therein or in or on gambling apparatus or material used in
connection with or promotion of gambling or gambling places.
(Ord. 189, passed 5-27-1943)
§ 118.121 TABULATION OF ALL SEIZED PROPERTY.
   When any member of the Police Department, or any other officer, in the
execution of a search warrant issued under the provisions of this subchapter
shall find any stolen or embezzled property or shall seize any of the other
things for which a search warrant is allowed, the officer shall make a complete
and accurate tabulation of all property and money so seized and shall file a
copy of the tabulation forthwith with the court or magistrate and the property
and money so seized shall be suppressed by order of the court until the final
disposition of the case, unless otherwise ordered.
(Ord. 189, passed 5-27-1943)
§ 118.122 SEIZED PROPERTY TO BE STORED.
   All the property and things so seized under this subchapter shall be safely
kept by the direction of the court or magistrate, issuing a search warrant so
long as shall be necessary for the purpose of being produced or used as
evidence during any trial.
(Ord. 189, passed 5-27-1943)
§ 118.123 PROPERTY TO BE RESTORED TO OWNER.
   All stolen or embezzled property shall be restored to the owner thereof as
soon as may be afterwards, and all other things seized by virtue of any warrant
shall be, upon conviction, destroyed under the discretion of the court,
providing, however, that pursuant to the provisions of Public Act 122, being
M.C.L.A. § 205.13, as amended by Public Act 615 of 2006, being M.C.L.A. §
445.2001, any monies and other useful property lawfully seized and not stolen
or embezzled, shall be, upon conviction, turned over to the city if the same
was seized by its officers under a search warrant duly issued, and all monies
shall be credited to the General Fund of the city.
(Ord. 189, passed 5-27-1943)
§ 118.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Generally. Any person violating any provision of this chapter for
which no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.999.
   (B)   Mechanical games and music vending machines. Any person convicted of
violating any of the provisions of §§
118.001 through
118.036 shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $500 or imprisonment not to
exceed 90 days, or by both a fine and imprisonment.
(Ord. 376, passed 4-26-1977)
   (C)   Billiard rooms, pool halls and bowling alleys. Every person, firm or
corporation convicted of violating any of the provisions of §§
118.050 through
118.059 shall be punished by a fine of not to exceed $100 and costs of
prosecution and, in default of the payment of the fine and costs, the court may
make a further sentence that the offender be imprisoned in the Wayne County
Jail, or another place of imprisonment as may be hereafter established by the
City Council as a place of confinement, until the fine and costs be paid, but
not longer than 90 days, or, in the discretion of the court having jurisdiction
of the cause, both a fine and imprisonment may be imposed. In the event that
there shall be imposed upon any corporation any fine and costs, or either, or
both, for the violation of any of the terms of §§
118.050 through
118.059, then it shall be lawful to collect the fine and costs, or either, or
both, in an action of assumpsit before any court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 70, passed 8-2-1928)
   (D)   Public shows, exhibitions and amusements. In addition to any other
penalty or punishment hereinbefore provided, every person or persons, firm or
corporation convicted of violating any of the provisions of §§
118.070 through
118.079 shall be punished by a fine of not to exceed $100 and costs of
prosecution and, in default of the payment of the fine and costs, the court may
make a further sentence that the offender be imprisoned in the Wayne County
Jail, or another place of imprisonment as may be hereafter established by the
City Council as a place of confinement, until the fine and costs be paid, but
not longer than 90 days, or, in the discretion of the court having jurisdiction
of the cause, both a fine and imprisonment may be imposed. In the event that
there shall be imposed upon any corporation any fine and costs, or either, or
both, for the violation of any of the terms of §§
118.070 through
118.079, then it shall be lawful to collect the fine and costs, or either, or
both, in an action of assumpsit before any court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 63, passed 1-22-1929)
   (E)   Public dance hall. Each and every violation, or failure to comply with
the provisions of §§
118.095 through
118.105 shall be cause for revocation of the license issued hereunder and shall
also be punished by a fine of not to exceed $100 and costs of prosecution and,
in default of the payment of the fine and costs, the court may make a further
sentence that the offender be imprisoned in the Wayne County Jail, or another
place of imprisonment as may be hereafter established by the City Council as a
place of confinement, until the fine and a costs be paid, but not longer than
90 days, or, in the discretion of the court having jurisdiction of the cause,
both a fine and imprisonment may be imposed, in the event that there shall be
imposed upon any corporation any fine and costs, or either, or both, for the
violation of any of the terms of §§
118.095 through
118.105, then it shall be lawful to collect the fine and costs, or either, or
both, in an action of assumpsit before any court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 56, passed 8-2-1928)

RESTAURANTS
§ 119.001 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this subchapter, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      CLASS A RESTAURANT, BUFFET, LUNCH ROOM, LUNCH COUNTER, PUBLIC DINING HALL
OR PLACE WHERE VICTUALS AND FOOD ARE PREPARED OR MANUFACTURED. Every
restaurant, buffet, lunch room, lunch counter, dining room of hotel and every
other place where food is served, sold or consumed on the premises and where
beer, whiskey, wine, or other spiritous and/or intoxicating liquor is served
with the food and shall include restaurants as defined in Public Act 8 of 1933
(Extra Session), § 1, being M.C.L.A. §§ 436.1801 through 426.1815.
      CLASS D RESTAURANT, BUFFET, LUNCH ROOM, LUNCH COUNTER, PUBLIC DINING HALL
OR PLACE WHERE VICTUALS AND FOOD ARE PREPARED OR MANUFACTURED. Every
restaurant, buffet, lunch room, lunch counter, dining room of hotel and every
other place where food is served, sold or consumed on the premises and where no
beer, whiskey, wine or other spiritous and/or intoxicating liquor is served,
sold or consumed in the premises.
   (B)   License for Class A establishment required. No person, firm or
corporation shall keep, maintain or operate a Class A restaurant, buffet, lunch
room, lunch counter, public dining hall or place where the victuals and food
are prepared or manufactured in the city without first having obtained a
license from the City Clerk.
   (C)    License for Class D establishment required. No person, firm or
corporation shall keep, maintain or operate a Class D restaurant, buffet, lunch
room, lunch counter, public dining hall or place where the victuals and food
are prepared or manufactured in the city, without first having obtained a
license from the City Clerk.
(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923; Am. Ord. 121, passed 12-28-1933; Am. Ord. 138,
passed 2-7-1935) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.002 LICENSE FEE.
   (A)   The license fee for businesses herein designated as Class A shall be
$10. The license fee for businesses herein designated as Class D shall be $5.
Licenses issued under the provisions of this subchapter shall cover but one
place of business, which shall be stated therein, and shall not be assignable
except by resolution of the City Council. Every license shall expire on May 1
of each year, unless sooner revoked by the City Council for cause. In case the
time intervening between the date of application and the date of expiration
shall be three months or less, the City Treasurer shall collect only one-half
of the license fee herein prescribed.
   (B)    Application for the license shall be made in writing and shall be
upon printed blanks to be furnished by the City Clerk, and shall set forth,
among other things, the place where the business is to be conducted, the name
of the person, firm or corporation by whom the business is to be carried on and
the place of residence of the applicant. The application shall also contain an
agreement by which the applicant consents and agrees that the inspectors of the
Health Department, Fire Department and Police Department may enter and inspect
any part of the premises used in conducting the business or manufacturing any
victuals or food products for the purpose of analysis. Applications for Class A
restaurants, buffets, lunch rooms, lunch counters, public dining halls or
places where the victuals and food are prepared or manufactured in the city,
shall also contain an agreement that the applicant will abide by and comply
with the laws of the Untied States and the state relative to the sale of
alcoholic liquors and the rules and regulations of the Liquor Commission of the
state.
   (C)   No license shall be granted to conduct a Class A restaurant, buffet,
lunch room, lunch counter, public dining hall or place where the victuals and
food are prepared or manufactured within a radius of 250 feet of any church or
school unless written permission therefor, signed by the priest or minister of
the church or the superintendent of the school, is submitted with the
application.
   (D)   No license shall be granted to conduct a Class A restaurant, buffet,
lunch room, lunch counter, public dining hall or place where the victuals and
food are prepared or manufactured to any person, firm or corporation who is
delinquent in the payment of personal taxes.
(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923; Am. Ord. 121, passed 12-28-1933; Am. Ord. 138,
passed 2-7-1935; Am. Ord. 156, passed 3-26-1936) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.003 INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   Before a license can be issued by the City Clerk on the application
for either a Class A or Class D restaurant, buffet, lunch room, lunch counter,
public dining hall or place where victuals and food are prepared or
manufactured in the city, the application shall be presented to the health
officer and the Chief of the Fire Department as hereinafter provided in this
subchapter.
   (B)   The City Clerk shall submit to the City Council the application
together with the report of the Chief of Police, health officer and the Chief
of the Fire Department thereon. If the Council shall find, as a result of its
investigation and the reports made to it by the officers hereinbefore
mentioned, that the applicant is of good moral character and is a suitable
person to conduct and operate a restaurant, buffer, lunch room, lunch counter,
public dining hall or place where victuals and food are prepared or
manufactured and, in cases where application is made for a license to conduct
the business herein designated as Class A, that the applicant is a citizen of
the United States, it shall direct the City Clerk to issue a license therefor,
and thereupon, the City Clerk shall issue a license to conduct and operate the
business upon the payment of the license fee herein prescribed.
(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.004 BUILDING AND EQUIPMENT TO CONFORM.
   Before the health officer shall approve the application set forth in §
119.001, he or she shall be satisfied that the building and equipment for the
business conforms to the following rules.
   (A)   Floors. Tight and solid, easily washed.
   (B)   Walls and ceilings. Constructed of material that will make tight and
smooth surface easily cleanable.
   (C)   Building. To be properly lighted and ventilated.
   (D)   Equipment.
      (1)   Water running, hot and cold, connected to a three compartment metal
sink, except if a dish washing machine is provided which has a rinse of 180°F
of water.
         (a)   All multi-service, eating and drinking utensils including all
dishes, knives, forks, spoons, cups, glasses and the like, shall be thoroughly
cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process.
         (b)   All multi-use utensils, including pots, pans, urns, skillets and
the like, used in preparation of food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and
effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process immediately following
the day’s operation.
      (2)   Ice box, proper sewerage connections for the ice box and sink.
      (3)   Adequate toilet facilities for men and women.
      (4)   Garbage containers with covers.
   (E)   Basements. Not recognized unless built for handling and preparing
foods.
   (F)   Living or sleeping rooms. No living or sleeping rooms in direct
connection with any part of the restaurant will be tolerated.
(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923; Am. Ord. 271, passed 7-3-1962) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.005 CONDUCT OF BUSINESS.
   (A)   No licensee shall permit any disorderly conduct in his or her place of
business, nor shall any licensee permit his or her place of business to become
a resort or meeting place for thieves, prostitutes or other disorderly persons,
nor shall any licensee permit any gambling in his or her place of business or
permit the placing or use of any gambling apparatus or paraphernalia about his
or her premises, nor shall any licensee permit any lewd, obscene or immoral
exhibition or entertainment on his or her premises or any other conduct likely
to corrupt the morals of the youth.
   (B)   Licensees providing entertainment, amusement, exhibitions, music or
places for dancing shall comply with and abide by all rules and regulations of
the Police Department and other proper authorities relating thereto.
   (C)   All licensees operating under Class A licenses may open their places
of business at 5:00 a.m. and remain open not later than 2:00 a.m. of the
following morning and no longer.
   (D)   No licensee operating under a Class A license shall sell, procure for,
or furnish, directly or indirectly, to any minor under the age of 21 years, any
beer, wine, whiskey or other intoxicating liquor, nor permit any minor to
loiter in or about his or her place of business.
   (E)   No licensee operating under a Class A license shall employ any person
under the age of 21 years to do any work in connection with that place of
business.
(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923; Am. Ord. 121, passed 12-28-1933) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.006 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   Whenever the business shall be carried on in conjunction with some other
form of business which, under a provision of the regulations regulating the
same, shall be required to close at a particular hour or remain closed until a
particular time, then the business herein proposed to be licensed shall be
closed according to the provisions of the regulations covering the business
operated in connection therewith.
(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.007 FEES TO BE DEPOSITED IN GENERAL FUND.
   The money derived from the issuance of the licenses shall be turned over to
the City Treasurer and deposited in the General Fund of the city.
(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.008 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE.
   (A)   The City Council may, at any time, for sufficient cause proved to the
satisfaction of the Council after notice and hearing, suspend or revoke any
license granted under the provisions of this subchapter and order the business
so licensed to be closed.
   (B)   After the notice closing the business, no business of the nature
herein proposed to be licensed shall be conducted or carried on in the place
until a new license shall have been issued under the provisions of this
subchapter and the issuance thereof approved by the City Council or the
suspension imposed by the City Council be lifted.
(Ord. 38, passed 5-26-1923) Penalty, see §
119.999
PUBLIC MARKETS
§ 119.020 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   HUCKSTER. Any person who sells food or other products not produced,
manufactured or made by himself or herself, which he or she has purchased for
resale, by virtue of or which have been consigned for him or her for sale.
   MARKET MASTER. Any person who, by virtue of owning, leasing, or controlling
vacant property, rents or leases, stands, stalls or places the same thereon for
the buying and selling of articles of food.
   PERSON. All natural persons, firms, partnerships, corporations and all
associations of natural persons, incorporated or unincorporated, whether acting
by themselves or by a servant, agent or employee. All PERSONS who violate any
of the provisions of this subchapter, whether as owner or as agent, servant or
employee, shall, except as herein otherwise provided, be equally liable as
principals.
   PRODUCER. Any person who vends in a public market, articles or products
grown or produced by him, her or any member of his or her family residing with
him or her upon property owned, rented or controlled by him or her. It shall
include any person who represents exclusively a non-profit association of
producers of farm products which markets the products produced by its members.
   PUBLIC MARKET or MARKET PLACE. A place on vacant property used for buying
and selling farm products and the accommodation of producers’ and hucksters’
wagons in which the products are brought to or taken from the place.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930; Am. Ord. 153, passed 11-29-1935; Am. Ord. 158,
passed 10-6-1936)
§ 119.021 PUBLIC MARKET; LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall establish or conduct a public market or market place as
herein defined within the corporate limits of the city without first having
obtained a license from the City Clerk. Application for the license shall be
made in writing to the City Clerk and shall be upon printed blanks to be
furnished by the City Clerk, which shall set forth, among other things, the
place where the business is to be conducted, the name, age, residence and
previous experience of the applicant. If the applicant be a partnership, the
names and addresses of all partners and the name under which the business is to
be conducted shall be given. If the applicant is a corporation, the names and
addresses of all the officers and the name of the corporation shall be given.
The application shall, before the issuance of the license, be referred to the
health officer, who shall make an investigation and recommendation to the City
Clerk within a reasonable time after the filing of the application. If the City
Clerk is satisfied that the applicant is a suitable person to conduct a public
market or market place, has never been convicted of a felony, that the proposed
public market or market place is equipped with one automatic dial scale of 300
pounds capacity and one computing scale of 100 pounds capacity, sealed by the
Sealer of Weights and Measures (the scales to be located for the convenience of
customers in checking the weights of purchases), then he or she shall grant the
license upon the payment to the City Treasurer of a license fee in the amount
of $200 and the filing with the City Clerk of a surety company bond in the
amount of $1,000 conditioned for the faithful observance of the terms of this
subchapter or any ordinance amendatory thereof or supplemental hereto.
Provided, however, that no license shall be granted to any person, firm,
partnership or corporation to operate or conduct a public market or market
place within a radius of 2,000 feet of any other market or market place
licensed under the provisions of this subchapter.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930; Am. Ord. 105, passed 8-18-1932; Am. Ord. 150,
passed 10-24-1935) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.022 PRODUCER OR HUCKSTER; LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   No producer or huckster shall engage in his or her business in a
public market or market place within the corporate limits of the city without
first having obtained a licence therefor from the City Clerk. Application for a
producer’s license to engage in business in a public market or market place
shall be made in writing upon blanks furnished by the City Clerk, giving the
name, age, address and previous experience of the applicant, the names and
kinds of the products he or she produces and intends to sell at the market, the
place where he or she raises the products, the names of all persons in his or
her employ who shall appear at the market to sell the products the names of all
persons employed by him or her at the premises where he or she raises the
products and any other information as may be deemed necessary for the
protection of the public welfare and the proper enforcement of this subchapter,
together with an agreement that, if license is granted to him or her, he or she
will not allow or permit anyone to sell his or her products in a market other
than the members of his or her immediate family or the persons actually
employed by him or her in the raising of produce and that a violation of the
agreement shall be sufficient cause for the revocation of his or her license.
The City Clerk may require all information to be sworn to be the applicant. The
application shall be referred to the health officer who shall make an
investigation and recommendation to the City Clerk within a reasonable time
after receiving the application. If the City Clerk if satisfied that the
applicant is a suitable person to engage in the business, has not been
convicted of any felony, or the offense of short weight, or been barred from
any public market, he or she shall grant the license and issue the same upon
the payment to the City Treasurer of the license fee of $1.
   (B)   Application for huckster’s license shall be made in writing upon
blanks furnished by the City Clerk, giving the name, age, address and previous
experience of the applicant, the names and kinds of the products he or she
intends to sell at the market and any other information as may be deemed
necessary for the protection of the public welfare and the proper enforcement
of this subchapter. The City Clerk may require all information to be sworn to
by the applicant. The application shall be referred to the health officer who
shall make an investigation and recommendation to the City Clerk within a
reasonable time after receiving the application. If the City Clerk is satisfied
that the applicant is a suitable person to engage in the business, has not been
convicted of a felony, or the offense of short weight, or been barred from any
public market, he or she shall grant a license and issue the same upon the
payment to the City Treasurer of the license fee of $25.
   (C)   At the time of the issuance of the license, the City Clerk shall give
to each producer or huckster a suitable plate to be displayed by the licensee
in a conspicuous place at the stall where he or she engages in his or her
business in the public market. No producer or huckster shall operate more than
one stall under one license.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930; Am. Ord. 105, passed 8-18-1932) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.023 RESTRICTION FOR HUCKSTER.
   No huckster who has been licensed to peddle on the streets and alleys of the
city shall do business within 500 feet of any public market. The huckster shall
not do business in any public market in the city unless he or she first obtains
the license required by this subchapter. It shall be unlawful for any producer
to sell his or her products on the streets, alleys or public places of the city
without first obtaining a license therefor.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.024 ARTICLES ALLOWED TO BE SOLD IN PUBLIC MARKETS.
   (A)   The following articles are allowed to be sold in public markets or
market places: any article of food or food products of any nature whatsoever,
provided that the handling, sale and storage of same complies with all sanitary
regulations of the Health Department and the regulations of the city. It shall
be unlawful to sell, display, expose or offer for sale any other articles than
food or food products in a public market, or to sell, display, expose or offer
for sale, or demonstrate or solicit patronage for any business, merchandise,
goods or real estate.
   (B)   The term FOOD as used herein, shall include all articles used for
food, drink, confectionery or condiment intended to be eaten or drank by man or
other animals, whether simple, mixed or compound.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930; Am. Ord. 126, passed 7-3-1934) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.025 INSPECTION.
   All articles of food in a public market shall be subject to the inspection
of the health officer at all reasonable times.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.026 PRODUCTS UNLAWFUL TO SELL.
   It shall be unlawful to sell, offer or expose for sale in any public market
any adulterated, bad, diseased, impure or unwholesome articles of food or food
products. It shall be the duty of the market master to prevent the display of
those articles.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.027 GARBAGE AND RUBBISH RECEPTACLES.
   The market master shall furnish suitable garbage and rubbish receptacles of
a number and type required and approved by the health officer of the city. It
shall be his or her duty to cause producers and hucksters to deposit all
garbage and rubbish in the receptacles.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.028 SANITATION REQUIREMENTS.
   Producers and hucksters are hereby required to thoroughly clean their
stalls, stands or places after market hours and before leaving the same. No
person shall deposit vegetable refuse or other garbage, broken crates, boxes,
barrels or pieces thereof, paper or other rubbish in any place in a public
market except in the proper permanent concrete or iron or steel receptacles
which shall be erected by the market master. It shall be unlawful to burn any
garbage or rubbish in any public market.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.029 UNLAWFUL TO RENT TO UNLICENSED PERSON.
   It shall be unlawful for a market master to rent or allow the use of any
stall stand or place in any public market or market place to any person who is
not licensed under the provisions of this subchapter.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.030 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   A violation of the provisions of this subchapter, a conviction of the charge
of having violated any other ordinance of the city, repeated verified
complaints against any producer or huckster who sells in a public market,
giving reasonable conclusive evidence that the person has practiced deception
in his or her dealings in the market by displaying or selling his or her
produce so packed and faced as to misrepresent the average quality or condition
of the produce in the package, or by knowingly giving false information
regarding the origin, variety, quality, condition or value of the products
which he or she sells, or by similar sharp practices, shall, in addition to any
other penalties which may be inflicted, be cause for the City Council to bar
the person from the privileges and grounds of the public markets for a period
of time as may be deemed advisable by the Council and to revoke the license
issued to the person. The action shall be preceded by a hearing before the City
Council at which the person involved shall have an opportunity to fully present
his or her defense against the charges made against him or her. It shall be
unlawful for the market master to permit any person barred as aforesaid by the
City Council to occupy any place in or do business in a public market.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.031 LICENSES AND RECEIPTS TO BE DISPLAYED AND FURNISHED.
   All producers and hucksters shall display their licenses and furnish signed
receipts for goods purchased upon request. Stalls, stands or places occupied by
hucksters in a public market shall be plainly designated as that by appropriate
signs furnished by the market master and approved by the health officer or City
Manager’s designee.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.032 HEALTH OFFICER SUPERVISION.
   Public markets and market places shall be under the supervision of the
health officer of the city or any officer so authorized by the City Manager.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930)
§ 119.033 EXPIRATION OF LICENSE.
   All licenses issued hereunder shall expire on May 30 each year unless sooner
revoked by the City Council for cause. No license shall be issued for less than
one year, nor shall any license be assigned or transferred to any other person.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.034 BUILDING AND EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   Before the health officer or City Manager’s designee shall approve the
application for a public market or market place, he or she shall be satisfied
that the building and equipment for the business conform to the following
rules.
   (A)   Floor. Tight and solid, constructed of concrete or similar substance,
easily washed and flushed.
   (B)   Garbage and rubbish receptacles. Of a number and type required by the
health officer with covers.
   (C)   Equipment. Permanent roof over dressed meat, fish and poultry. Cases
and counters containing meat, fish and poultry to be protected by partitions of
glass, wood or metal so erected as to keep the same in a cleanly and sanitary
manner to meet the approval of the food inspector of the city, the meat, fish
and poultry to be kept and displayed so that it shall not be exposed to the
elements.
   (D)   Drainage facilities. To be approved by the health officer or City
Manager’s designee.
   (E)   Adequate toilet facilities. For men and women.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.035 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (A)   Public markets and market places licensed under the provisions of this
subchapter shall be closed at 6:00 p.m. each day, with the exception of
Thursday of each week, and kept closed until 4:00 a.m. of the following day; on
Thursday of each week the public markets and market places shall be closed at
8:00 p.m. and kept closed until 4:00 a.m. of the following day.
   (B)   Provided, however, that the markets and market places shall be closed
all day on the first day of each week, commonly called Sunday.
   (C)   After the closing of the public markets and market places, it shall be
the duty of the market master to see that the place is thoroughly cleaned and
the floors flushed.
(Ord. 91, passed 7-22-1930; Am. Ord. 105, passed 8-18-1932) Penalty, see §
119.999
SALE OF TAINTED MEAT, VEGETABLES AND OTHER FOODSTUFFS
§ 119.050 PROHIBITING THE SALE OR OFFERING FOR SALE, OR HAVING IN POSSESSION
FOR THE PURPOSE OF SELLING OR OFFERING FOR SALE, OF ANY DECAYED, TAINTED OR
SPOILED MEATS, VEGETABLES OR OTHER FOOD STUFFS.
   No person or firm or corporation shall sell, offer for sale, or have in
possession for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any decayed,
tainted or spoiled meat, vegetables or food stuffs of any kind, within the
city.
(Ord. 60, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.051 VIOLATION.
   Each and every person who shall sell, offer for sale, or have in possession
for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any decayed, tainted or
spoiled meat, vegetables, food stuffs of any kind within the city, either as
principal, officer, agent or employee shall be deemed to be violating the
provisions of this subchapter.
(Ord. 60, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.052 KEEPING TAINTED FOOD NEAR GOOD FOOD PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE OF
VIOLATION.
   The having or keeping of any decayed, tainted or spoiled meat, vegetables or
food stuffs of any kind in any refrigerator, ice box or case, wherein are
usually kept good meat, vegetables or other food stuffs to be sold or offered
for sale in the city, shall be deemed prima facie evidence of the violation of
terms of this subchapter.
(Ord. 60, passed 8-2-1928) Penalty, see §
119.999
§ 119.053 INSPECTION.
   It shall be the duty of the health officer and food inspector of the city or
City Manager’s designee to investigate the premises in every case where there
is reasonable ground to believe that decayed, tainted or spoiled meat,
vegetables or food stuffs of any kind are being sold, offered for sale, or had
in the possession for the purpose of offering for sale, and for that purpose
